awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding Bacterial Flagellar Propulsion
awd_abstract_narration:
Bacteria such as Escherichia coli and Salmonella typhimurium swim through a fluid by rotating their helical flagella. Understanding the swimming mechanism of bacteria with flagella is a challenging subject that involves interactions between the biological, engineering, mathematical, and physical sciences.  Although many scientists have studied bacterial swimming, experimental and theoretical studies have both shown that it is difficult to understand the dynamic behavior of the flagellum because of its complex geometry during locomotion, and many open questions remain.  This project will develop and validate improved mathematical models for such bacterial motility.
 
The goals of this project are to: (1) develop detailed mathematical models accompanied by the numerical schemes to understand bacterial motility by means of flagella; (2) analyze the complicated hydrodynamic interactions among multiple flagella arising from the cell body in fluids; (3) validate the models by comparing the results to experimental data; and (4) use these models to make predictions that will be verified by further experimentation. This project also heavily involves the development of an adaptive version of the generalized immersed boundary method which will find numerous applications in biological fluid dynamics such as supercoiling DNA dynamics. The new numerical algorithm will be freely distributed on-line within IBAMR software. The results obtained from this research on free swimming bacteria may provide new information about the spread of infections and biofilm formation, and may help to design nanomachines that are self-propelled by flagella.

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative research project is part of a research program that aims to develop mathematical models that can provide a better understanding of how bacteria with flagella, such as Escherichia coli (E. coli), swim and interact with their environment. We are working to develop mathematical models of swimming bacteria that can be informed by experiments, to study cell-cell interactions in complex fluids to understand bacterial communities, such as those that form a biofilm, and to help to design nanomachines which use flagellar filaments for propulsion. The specific outcomes of the part of this project based at UNC-Chapel Hill are primarily related to the creation and benchmarking of numerical methods and computational software for performing computer simulations based on these mathematical models.

The intellectual merit of this project is primarily related to the construction and testing of adaptive numerical methods for simulating the dynamics of complex biological fluids, such as mucus. Complex fluids present challenges for modeling and simulation that are beyond those encountered in Newtonian fluid models. This project developed new computational methods for simulating the dynamics of complex (polymeric) fluid flows that allow for the use of adaptive mesh refinement (AMR), which enables fine computational grids to be dynamically deployed near features of interest within the simulation. In this project, these methods have been interfaced with computational approaches to modeling the interaction between fluids and structures that are based on the immersed boundary method and the immersed interface method. Models of bacterial flagella beating within a complex fluid were developed in this project using the generalized immersed boundary method, which describes the dynamics of long, thin structures. We are completing a study on non-Newtonian flow effects on flagellar pumping efficacy that relies on the methods developed in this project. Several peer-reviewed papers have resulted from this project, and we expect that several more will be published based on research results completed during the course of this award.

The broader impacts of this project are primarily related to the development of open-source computational software based on the computational methods developed in the project. These methods are being incorporated into the open-source IBAMR software, which is a resource available to the broader research community. Complex fluids models have broad applicability in biology and also in industrial applications, and there are relatively few freely available open-source codes available for simulating such fluid flows. The project has also provided human resource development by supporting a graduate research assistant through the duration of the project.
